perturbation.original_text:
6.1 When providing the Program Content to Party B, Party A may specify the special purpose for which such Program Content shall be used, the extent to which such Program Content shall be transmitted, the time or times at which such Program Content shall be transmitted 
(including the time at which such Program Content is published on the Phoenix Satellite TV Website or Other 
 Websites, or the time at which such Program Content is licensed to any third party by Party B), and the manner by which such Program 
Content shall be transmitted (including the manner by which such Program Content is published on the Phoenix Satellite TV Websites 
or Other Websites, or the manner in which such Program Content shall be used by the licensed third party). Party B’s use of the 
Program Content shall be in strict compliance with Party A’s requirements.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.1 When providing the Program Content to Party B, Party A may specify the special purpose for which such Program Content shall be used. However, Party B shall have ultimate discretion on the extent to which such Program Content shall be transmitted, the time or times at which such Program Content shall be transmitted 
(including the time at which such Program Content is published on the Phoenix Satellite TV Website or Other 
 Websites, or the time at which such Program Content is licensed to any third party by Party B), and the manner by which such Program 
Content shall be transmitted (including the manner by which such Program Content is published on the Phoenix Satellite TV Websites 
or Other Websites, or the manner in which such Program Content shall be used by the licensed third party). Party B’s use of the 
Program Content shall generally align with Party A's guidance but remains at Party B's sole determination.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that Party B's use of the Program Content must strictly comply with Party A's requirements. The modified version introduces a contradiction by granting Party B 'ultimate discretion' and 'sole determination' regarding transmission extent, timing, and manner, effectively negating the strict compliance requirement and creating uncertainty about the enforceability of Party A's specifications.
perturbation.location: ARTICLE SIX PARTY B’S OBLIGATIONS WITH RESPECT TO CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION

perturbation.original_text:
9.2 Upon confirmation by the licensor in writing prior to the expiration of the term hereof, this Agreement may be extended for as long as may be 
agreed to by both the licensor and licensee through negotiation, provided, however, that the licensee shall not have the right to decide 
the extension of the term hereof.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.2 Upon confirmation by either the licensor or the licensee in writing prior to the expiration of the term hereof, this Agreement may be extended for as long as may be 
agreed to by both the licensor and licensee through negotiation. The licensee shall have an equal right to decide 
the extension of the term hereof.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states the licensee does not have the right to decide the extension of the term. The modified version directly contradicts this by stating the licensee *does* have an equal right to decide the extension of the term, creating uncertainty about the renewal process.

perturbation.original_text:
13.1 Party B may not assign its rights and obligations hereunder without Party A’s consent in writing and the successors and permitted assigns of 
the Parties shall be bound by this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
13.1 Party B may assign its rights and obligations hereunder with notification to Party A. Party A will retain final approval, except in cases of acquisition. The successors and permitted assigns of 
the Parties shall be bound by this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states Party B *may not* assign rights without Party A's *consent*. The modified version allows assignment with only *notification,* but also states Party A retains *final approval*, then adds an *exception* for acquisitions where such approval is not needed. This creates a three-way conflict; Party B can assign with notification but still needs approval, except when acquired where no consent is needed.
